page.title: 04HISTORY OF GERRICK AREA
page.content: Freeborough Hill is a large, conical, geological formation rising above the peneplain level of the Yorkshire Moors. It was once quarried for sandstone. There are numerous Bronze Age tumuli scattered about the high ground of Moorsholm and Gerrick Moors. Those named include {Three Howes} and {Herd {Howe}. Crosses stand out which indicate tracks across the otherwise featureless moors. Some socket stones and broken shafts remain. The crosses are all named. e.g. Job Cross, Siss Cross.
